Definition: The direct costs attributable to the production of the goods sold by a company.
An arrangement between a financial institution and a customer that establishes a maximum loan balance that the lender permits the borrower to access.
Cash and other assets that are expected to be converted to cash within a year.
A company's debts or obligations that are due within one year.
When a firm raises money for working capital or capital expenditures by selling bonds, bills, or notes to individual and/or institutional investors.
The reduction in the value of an asset over time, due to wear and tear.
A reduction in the ownership percentage of a share of stock caused by the issuance of new shares.
A bond that is issued for less than its par (or face) value, or a bond currently trading for less than its par value in the secondary market.
The sum of declared dividends issued by a company for every ordinary share outstanding.
A measure of a firm's profit that includes all expenses except interest and income tax expenses.
The earnings per share for the most recent 12-month period divided by the current market price per share.
The process of raising capital through the sale of shares in an enterprise.
The nominal value or dollar value of a security stated by the issuer.
A method of measuring a security's intrinsic value by examining related economic, financial, and other qualitative and quantitative factors.
A collection of commonly-followed accounting rules and standards for financial reporting.
Non-public facts about a company known by its employees and other individuals with a duty of confidentiality.
The extent to which a market allows assets to be bought and sold at stable prices.
The value of all the non-financial and financial assets owned by an individual or institution minus the value of all its outstanding liabilities.
A measure of profitability that shows the percentage of revenue that exceeds operating costs.
The loss of potential gain from other alternatives when one alternative is chosen.
The ongoing administrative expenses of a business that are not directly attributable to a specific business activity.
The time required for the return on an investment to repay the sum of the original investment.
A constant stream of identical cash flows with no end.
A dividend that is accrued and paid on a company's preferred shares.
A method of calculating financial results using certain projections or presumptions.
A formal legal document required by and filed with the SEC that provides details about an investment offering for sale to the public.
The authority to act on behalf of a shareholder for the purpose of voting at a shareholder meeting.
A principle that defines the relationship between the price of European put and call options of the same class.
A preliminary prospectus filed by a company with the SEC, usually in connection with an IPO.
The portion of net income that is retained by the corporation rather than distributed to its owners as dividends.
A performance measure used to evaluate the efficiency or profitability of an investment.
The theoretical rate of return of an investment with zero risk.
The owners' residual interest in the assets of a corporation, after deducting liabilities.
The total number of shares of a particular stock that have been sold short by investors but have not yet been covered or closed out.
Debt issued by a national government in a foreign currency in order to finance the issuing country's growth.
A public financial market in which financial instruments or commodities are traded for immediate delivery.
A privilege, sold by one party to another, that gives the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a stock at an agreed-upon price within a certain period.
A pre-packaged investment strategy based on derivatives such as a single security, a basket of securities, options, indices, commodities, debt issuance, and/or foreign currencies.
A type of loan offered to individuals who do not qualify for conventional loans due to their poor credit scores.
A derivative contract through which two parties exchange financial instruments, such as interest rates, commodities, or currencies.
A legal claim by a government entity against a noncompliant taxpayer's assets.
A public offer to purchase some or all of shareholders' shares in a corporation.
An abbreviation used to uniquely identify publicly traded shares of a particular stock on a particular stock market.
The concept that money available at the present time is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its potential earning capacity.
The actual rate of return of an investment or a pool of investments over a given evaluation period.
The difference between a country's imports and its exports.
A formal document which outlines the terms of a trust agreement.
A cost that varies with the level of output.
The process by which an employee accrues non-forfeitable rights over employer-provided stock incentives or employer contributions to a retirement plan.
A derivative that confers the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a security, usually equity, at a certain price before expiration.
The difference between the yields on different debt instruments, calculated by deducting the yield of one instrument from another.
